Incident.Summary: Traffic stop resulting in a DUI / DWI arrest.

IncidentSuppNarrative.NarrativeText:
***The in-car cameras assigned to W-27 and my body worn camera were operational. ***

Defendant: Duc Jazet Momo
Date of Birth: 07/26/1996
Date of Arrest: 06/10/2023
Times of Arrest: 2249 hours
DUI #: 23-038 / 23-MSP-020866

CERTIFICATES AND TRAINING

* Trained in administering standardized field sobriety tests through the Maryland State Police and National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.
*Trained and certified through the Maryland State Police as a RADAR / LIDAR operator.
*ARIDE (Advanced Roadside Impaired Driving Enforcement) - May 2017.
*Cannabis Impairment Detection Workshop - June 2021.
*Graduate of the 2021 University of Maryland Institute of Advanced Law Enforcement Studies, DUI Institute.


VEHICLE IN MOTION

                On 06/10/2023 at approximately 2225 hours, I (TFC Hook) was on routine patrol in unmarked MSP unit W-27. I was traveling north on Garrett Highway in the area of Bear Creek Road, Accident, Garrett County, Maryland. While traveling north, I observed a black Nissan Sentra bearing a Maryland registration of 9FF3249 traveling south towards me. The Nissan appeared to be traveling at an extremely high rate of speed, above the posted speed limit of 55 MPH. I activated the front antenna of the Kustom Golden Eagle II radar unit (50001727) assigned to W-27, in moving mode opposite direction, and captured a speed reading of 86 MPH. The Nissan was the only vehicle in my field of view at that time. (The radar unit was tested before and after the stop and found to be working properly.) I quickly turned to catch up to the Nissan to conduct a traffic stop. I activated my emergency equipment and the Nissan hit the brakes, began to slow, and merged to the shoulder, but continued to drive slow on the shoulder for a short distance before coming to a stop.  

PERSONAL CONTACT

                I made a drivers side approach, and observed the driver holding the steering wheel with both hands, and staring straight ahead. I had to shine my flashlight in his eyes to get his attention and to roll his window down. I introduced myself, gave the reason for the stop, and requested his driver’s license and registration. I immediately detected a strong odor of an alcoholic beverage emitting from the interior of the Nissan. As I began to speak with the driver, I observed his eyes to be extremely bloodshot. I could observe a black cup on the driver’s floor board, between the driver’s feet, and a bottle of juice behind the passenger seat. (The bottle had condensation on the exterior.) The driver provided me a Maryland driver’s license, from a black cardholder, that he located in a green zippered bag on the passenger seat. The driver was identified as Duc Jazet Momo (07/26/1996). I asked Momo how much he had to drink, and he stated “I had a tasting earlier, and then I stopped.” I asked Momo what he had to drink, and he stated he had Hennessy.  
                I returned to my patrol vehicle, began to conduct standard MVA checks, relayed all pertinent information to the McHenry Barrack PCO, and advised the barrack I would have the driver on field sobriety testing. I returned to the Nissan and asked Momo to step out and walk to the front of his vehicle. Momo then showed me on his telephone that he was only 10 minutes away from his destination and began to plea his case to let him continue on. Momo would comply and step out. As Momo stepped out, he appeared to be off balance and fell back against his vehicle. I had Momo walk to the front of his vehicle.  I asked Momo if would he consent to standard field sobriety testing, to which he questioned, but did agree to perform field sobriety testing.


PRE-ARREST SCREENING

     The evaluation was performed on the shoulder of Garrett Highway (pavement). The surface was smooth, level, and free from any obvious debris. The area was lit by my patrol vehicles headlights, my spotlight, and my flashlight. The forward-facing emergency lights were deactivated on my patrol vehicle. The weather was dark, clear, and approximately 65 degrees. Momo appeared to be in good physical condition and did not display any visible injuries. Momo was wearing Crocs (I advised Momo twice that he could take his Crocs off, and he refused both times), jeans, and a sleeveless shirt. Momo had a disheveled look and his zipper on his pants was undone. It also appeared Momo had a white powdery substance on his black jeans. In front of his vehicle, I could still detect a strong odor of an alcoholic beverage emitting from his breath and person as Momo would attempt to stand so he was not directly facing me.

I asked Momo the following questions: 

Injuries – None.
Medication – None.
Medical Conditions – Heart Murmur.

HORIZONTAL GAZE NYSTAGMUS (6/6 clues observed)

     The first test given was the Horizontal Gaze Nystagmus test. After explaining the test to Momo, I asked Momo if he understood the instructions, and he stated "Yes."

     1.) Lack of Smooth Pursuit - Present in both eyes
     2.) Distinct and Sustained Nystagmus at Maximum Deviation - Present in both eyes
     3.) Onset of Nystagmus Prior to 45 Degrees - Present in both eyes

Momo kept focusing on the bottom of my pen, and not the top of the pen where my finger was located. I asked Momo to reach out and touch the tip of my finger, and he missed the tip of my finger by approximately 2 inches. I had to ask Momo once to keep his head still and once to turn directly towards me, as he slightly bladed himself away from me.

VGN was present in both eyes.

WALK AND TURN (6/8 clues observed)

     Prior to Momo performing the test, I properly explained and demonstrated how the test should be conducted.  I asked Momo if he understood the instructions, and he stated, "Yes".

Instructional Stage: 
    
  1. Momo immediately started walking, and I had to ask him to return to the instructional position. Momo seemed confused on which foot was his right and which foot was his left.

Walking Stage (1st Nine):
 
  1. Momo raised his arms away from body for balance.
  2. Momo missed heel to toe once.

Walking Stage (2nd Nine.)
 
  1. Momo lost balance and stepped off-line on step one.
  2. Momo missed heel to toe once.
  3. Momo took 10 steps and then stopped at the bumper of his vehicle.

Turn:
   
             -Completed unsatisfactory, turned in one motion.


One Leg Stand (2/4 clues observed)
               
                Prior to Momo performing the test, I properly explained and demonstrated how the test should be conducted. I asked Momo if he understood the instructions, and he stated “Yes.”

*Momo now stated that he had broken toes on one of his feet.

Instructional Stage: 
     
                -Nothing to report.

Seconds 0-10:
     
  1. Momo raised his arms away from body for balance.

Seconds 11-20:
 
  1. Momo raised his arms away from body for balance.
  2. Momo began to sway left to right.

Seconds 21-30:
 
  1. Momo raised his arms from his body for balance.
  2. Momo continued to sway left to right for balance.


Momo was offered a PBT, and refused. After refusing the PBT, Momo stated he was going to get back into his vehicle and I had to stand in front of him to block him from walking back to his door.

ARREST

Based on the following, I had reason to believe Momo was driving a motor vehicle under the influence of alcohol:
 
* Momo driving 86 MPH in a posted 55 MPH.
* Strong odor of an alcoholic beverage emitting from Momo’s breath and person.
* Momo’s eyes being bloodshot.
* Momo having an empty cup between his feet and an open bottle of cold juice.
* Momo pleading his case that he only had 10 minutes to his destination.
* Momo stepping out of his vehicle and falling back against his vehicle.
* Momo’s admission to drinking Hennessy at a tasting.
* My observed signs of impairment as Momo completed field sobriety testing.
* PBT refusal.

                I placed Momo into custody at 2249 hours. Momo got very agitated and refused to put his hands behind his back after I had one handcuff on his right wrist. Momo began to ask for me to allow him to make a phone call. After a short conversation, Momo did turn and allow me to place the second handcuff on his left wrist. A mouth check was completed for any foreign objects, and he spit out the bubble gum he had in his mouth. Momo was placed into my patrol vehicle. At Momo's request, I got both of his cell phones, keys, and secured his Nissan on the shoulder. As I began to check the cup and bottle for an alcoholic beverage, Momo became aggravated and started yelling out the window at me that I was illegally searching his vehicle. Momo unbuckled his seat belt and was hanging out of the window. I returned my patrol vehicle and re-positioned Momo back in the passenger seat and put his seat belt back on. I observed that Momo had fresh guardrail damage the entire length of the passenger side of the Nissan. There were very fresh scratches consistent with guardrail damage and fresh dust. The Nissan was secured and Momo was transported to the McHenry Barrack for processing. While transporting Momo to the barrack, he remained very agitated and continued to yell and speak over me. Momo expressed his concern for being an African American and just wanted to make it home, and that he would pay any amount of money he needed. Once at the barrack, Momo was advised his rights via the DR15 and refused to submit to an intoximeter at 2316 hours. Cpl. Davis was present as an Intoximeter Operator.


INTOXIMETER RESULT: 

*** REFUSAL ***

                Momo was charged appropriately and provided a copy of all pertinent paperwork. As I attempted to explain all the paperwork to Momo, he would continue to interrupt me and question me. Momo was not polite or cooperative throughout the majority of the arrest process. Momo was released from the McHenry Barrack to a sober adult at approximately 2345 hours.
                Momo would return to the barrack on 06/11/2023 and made contact with Sgt. Bittinger. Momo stated that he could not locate his credit cards or driver’s license. Sgt. Bittinger advised that Momo stated that his credit cards and driver’s license were located in a case attached to his cell phone. I advised Sgt. Bittinger that he retrieved his driver’s license from the black case that was inside the green zippered bag. Sgt. Bittinger advised that a check of the barrack was completed and nothing was found. I completed a check of my patrol vehicle which also had negative results.

All events occurred in Garrett County, Maryland.

Case closed by arrest.
